title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: probability statistics, decoupling powerful technique reduces dependent sample statistic average statistic evaluated several independent sequences random variables . transformation allows complex dependent statistics analyzed using tools designed independent data. U-statistics, fundamental non-parametric statistics genomic analysis, decoupling provides way : Estimate variances accurately Construct valid confidence intervals Perform hypothesis testing dependence Analyze complex genomic metrics theoretical guarantees package implements theoretical framework developed de la Peña colleagues decoupling U-statistics, specifically optimized genomic data analysis.

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: U-statistic order 2 form: Un=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Xj)U_n = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, X_j) hh symmetric kernel function, X1,…,XnX_1, \dots, X_n potentially dependent observations.

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: decoupling principle replaces dependent pairs (Xi,Xj)(X_i, X_j) independent pairs (Xi,Yj)(X_i, Y_j) YjY_j independent copies XjX_j. decoupled version becomes: Un′=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Yj)U_n' = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, Y_j) appropriate conditions, UnU_n Un′U_n' similar asymptotic properties, Un′U_n' much easier analyze involves independent terms .

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: package implements Friedman-de la Peña decoupling method, provides strong theoretical guarantees approximation quality. method particularly well-suited genomic applications dependence structures complex can modeled evolutionary relationships.

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: DecoupleResult: Stores results decoupling analysis including original statistic, decoupled distribution, p-values UStatKernel: Represents kernel functions U-statistics metadata

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: decouple_u_stat(): Main function performing decoupling analysis run_genomic_case_study(): Case study DNA sequence diversity analysis analyze_gene_expression_correlations(): Case study gene expression correlation analysis hamming_distance_kernel(): Kernel DNA sequence comparison gene_expression_correlation_kernel(): Kernel gene expression analysis

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: Interpretation: analysis shows observed mean Hamming distance (25.34) significantly higher expected independence (24.87, p = 0.023). suggests sequences evolved constraints maintain higher diversity expected chance alone.
code: # Run the genomic case study result <- run_genomic_case_study(   num_sequences = 15,   sequence_length = 100,   B = 200,   seed = 123 ) #>  #> === Biological Interpretation === #> Original mean Hamming distance: 74.0667 #> Expected distance under independence: 69.1327 #> Observed distance is 3.80 standard deviations from independence expectation #> Significant evidence of dependence between sequences (p < 0.05) #> This suggests shared evolutionary history or functional constraints  # Plot the results plot(result, main = "DNA Sequence Diversity Analysis")

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: Interpretation: observed mean absolute correlation (0.48) significantly higher independence expectation (0.15, p < 0.001). provides strong evidence co-expression networks regulatory modules simulated data.
code: # Analyze gene expression correlations expr_result <- analyze_gene_expression_correlations(   num_genes = 30,   num_samples = 20,   B = 200,   seed = 123 ) #>  #> === Gene Expression Analysis === #> Original mean absolute correlation: 0.2246 #> Expected correlation under independence: 0.2527 #> Variance inflation factor: Inf #> No significant evidence of co-expression structure (p >= 0.05) #> Genes appear to be expressed independently  # Plot the results plot(expr_result, main = "Gene Expression Correlation Analysis")

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: package uses Rcpp high-performance computation supports parallel processing large datasets: C++ implementation provides 10-100x speedup compared pure R implementations genomic-scale data.
code: # For large datasets, use parallel processing large_result <- decouple_u_stat(   x = large_dataset,   kernel = my_kernel,   B = 1000,   parallel = TRUE )

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
code: # Install the package if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("UStatDecouple")  # Load the package library(UStatDecouple)  # Basic usage data <- load_example_sequences() kernel <- create_kernel(hamming_distance_kernel, "Hamming Distance") result <- decouple_u_stat(data, kernel, B = 500)

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: UStatDecouple package provides rigorous implementation probabilistic decoupling U-statistics, filling important gap Bioconductor’s statistical infrastructure . transforming dependent statistics independent averages, enables accurate inference complex genomic metrics. package particularly valuable : Analyzing evolutionary relationships DNA sequences Studying co-expression networks transcriptomics Validating statistical methods dependence Providing theoretical guarantees genomic analyses implementation bridges gap advanced probability theory practical genomic analysis, making sophisticated statistical techniques accessible bioinformaticians computational biologists.

title: UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: de la Peña, V. H. (1993). Decoupling inequalities tail probabilities multivariate U-statistics. Annals Probability, 806-816. de la Peña, V. H., & Giné, E. (1999). Decoupling: dependence independence. Springer Science & Business Media. Hoeffding, W. (1948). class statistics asymptotically normal distribution. Annals Mathematical Statistics, 19(3), 293-325.

code: @Manual{,   title = {UStatDecouple: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis},   author = {Dany Mukesha},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.99.0},   url = {https://danymukesha.github.io/UStatDecouple/}, }

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: UStatDecouple implements probabilistic decoupling techniques U-statistics, transforming dependent sample statistics averages independent sequences. package provides rigorous statistical tools genomic data analysis, enabling accurate variance estimation, hypothesis testing, confidence interval construction complex genomic metrics. package based theoretical framework developed de la Peña colleagues decoupling inequalities probability theory , specifically optimized biological sequence analysis genomic applications. framework realized S4 object-oriented design high-performance C++ (Rcpp) back-end implementation, addressing quadratic (O(n2)O(n^2)) complexity U-statistics. Parallel processing supported via BiocParallel, pre-defined biological kernels facilitate DNA sequence gene expression analyses. Vignettes case studies illustrating provide package practical applications methods.

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: can also install package directly GitHub using devtools package:
code: devtools::install_github("danymukesha/UStatDecouple")

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: Performing decoupled U-statistic analysis DNA sequence data. allows compute kernel-based distances, estimate distributions, visualize results efficiently.
code: library(UStatDecouple)  data <- load_example_sequences()  kernel <- create_kernel(hamming_distance_kernel, "Hamming Distance")  result <- decouple_u_stat(data, kernel, B = 500)  print(result) #> DecoupleResult object: #>   Original U-statistic: 2.0000 #>   Decoupled mean: 1.4696 #>   Decoupled SD: 0.2567 #>   Kernel: Hamming Distance #>   Method: Friedman-de la Pena Decoupling #>   P-value: 0.0388 #>   Z-score: 2.0663 #>   Significance: * (p = 0.0388)  plot(result)

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
code: result <- run_genomic_case_study(   num_sequences = 15,   sequence_length = 100,   B = 200 ) #>  #> === Biological Interpretation === #> Original mean Hamming distance: 74.0667 #> Expected distance under independence: 69.1327 #> Observed distance is 3.80 standard deviations from independence expectation #> Significant evidence of dependence between sequences (p < 0.05) #> This suggests shared evolutionary history or functional constraints

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
code: expr_result <- analyze_gene_expression_correlations(   num_genes = 30,   num_samples = 20,   B = 500 ) #> Warning: package 'MASS' was built under R version 4.4.2 #>  #> === Gene Expression Analysis === #> Original mean absolute correlation: 0.2255 #> Expected correlation under independence: 0.2512 #> Variance inflation factor: Inf #> No significant evidence of co-expression structure (p >= 0.05) #> Genes appear to be expressed independently

title: Probabilistic Decoupling for U-Statistics in Genomic Analysis
text: package implements Friedman-de la Peña decoupling method, transforms dependent U-statistics: Un=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Xj)U_n = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, X_j) independent versions: Un′=1(n2)∑1≤<j≤nh(Xi,Yj)U_n' = \frac{1}{\binom{n}{2}} \sum_{1 \leq < j \leq n} h(X_i, Y_j) YjY_j independent copies XjX_j. transformation enables use classical statistical methods designed independent data .

title: Decouple a U-statistic — decouple_u_stat

title: Decouple a U-statistic — decouple_u_stat
text: DecoupleResult object containing original decoupled statistics

title: Decouple a U-statistic — decouple_u_stat
code: # Generate synthetic DNA sequences set.seed(123) bases <- c("A", "C", "G", "T") sequences <- lapply(1:5, function(i) sample(bases, 20, replace = TRUE))  # Create kernel and run decoupling kernel <- create_kernel(hamming_distance_kernel, "Hamming Distance") result <- decouple_u_stat(sequences, kernel, B = 100)  # Print results result #> DecoupleResult object: #>   Original U-statistic: 15.4000 #>   Decoupled mean: 12.0850 #>   Decoupled SD: 1.8846 #>   Kernel: Hamming Distance #>   Method: Friedman-de la Pena Decoupling #>   P-value: 0.0786 #>   Z-score: 1.7590 #>   Significance:   (p = 0.0786)
